1.1: Adam fathered Seth, who fathered Enosh,
1.2: who fathered Kenan, who fathered Mahalalel, who fathered Jared,
1.3: who fathered Enoch, who fathered Methuselah, who fathered Lamech,
1.4: who fathered Noah, who fathered Shem, Ham, and Japheth.
1.5: Japheth’s descendants were Gomer, Magog, Madai, Javan, Tubal, Meshech, and Tiras.
1.6: Gomer’s descendants were Ashkenaz, Diphath, and Togarmah.
1.7: Javan’s descendants were Elishah, Tarshish, Kittim, and Rodanim.
1.8: Ham’s descendants were Cush, Mizraim, Put, and Canaan.
1.9:
Cush’s descendants were Seba, Havilah, Sabta, Raama, and Sabteca.
Raamah’s descendants were Sheba and Dedan.
1.10: Cush fathered Nimrod. He became the first powerful ruler on the earth.
1.11: Mitzraim fathered the Ludim, the Anamim, the Lehabim, the Naphtuhim,
1.12: the Pathrusim, the Casluhim (from whom the Philistines descended), and the Caphtorim.
1.13: Canaan fathered Sidon his firstborn, as well as Heth,
1.14: and the Jebusites, the Amorites, the Girgashites,
1.15: the Hivites, the Archites, the Sinites,
1.16: the Arvadites, the Zemarites, and the Hamathites.
1.17: Shem’s descendants were Elam, Asshur, Arpachshad, Lud, Aram, Uz, Hul, Gether, and Meshech.
1.18: Arpachshad fathered Shelah and Shelah fathered Eber.
1.19: Eber fathered two sons. The name of the one was Peleg (because the earth was divided during his lifetime) and his brother was named Joktan.
1.20: Joktan fathered Almodad, Sheleph, Hazarmaveth, Jerah,
1.23: Ophir, Havilah, and Jobab—all of these were Joktan’s descendants.
1.24: In summary, Shem fathered Arpachshad, who fathered Shelah,
1.25: who fathered Eber, who fathered Peleg, who fathered Reu,
1.26: who fathered Serug, who fathered Nahor, who fathered Terah,
1.28: Abraham’s descendants were Isaac and Ishmael.
1.29: These are their genealogies: the firstborn Ishmael fathered Nebaioth, and then Kedar, Adbeel, Mibsam,
1.31: Jetur, Naphish, and Kedemah—these are the Ishmaelites.
1.32: The descendants born to Keturah, Abraham’s mistress, were Zimran, Jokshan, Medan, Midian, Ishbak, and Shuah. The descendants of Jokshan were Sheba and Dedan.
1.33: The descendants of Midian were Ephah, Epher, Hanoch, Abida, and Eldaah. All these were the descendants of Keturah.
1.34: Abraham fathered Isaac. Isaac’s descendants were Esau and Israel.
1.35: Esau’s descendants were Eliphaz, Reuel, Jeush, Jalam, and Korah.
1.36: Eliphaz’s descendants were Teman, Omar, Zephi, Gatam, Kenaz, Timna, and Amalek.
1.37: Reuel’s descendants were Nahath, Zerah, Shammah, and Mizzah.
1.38: Seir’s descendants were Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, Anah, Dishon, Ezer, and Dishan.
1.39: Lotan’s descendants were Hori and Homam. Lotan’s sister was Timna.
1.40:
Shobal’s descendants were Alian, Manahath, Ebal, Shephi, and Onam.
Zibeon’s descendants were Aiah and Anah.
1.41:
Anah’s descendant was Dishon.
Dishon’s descendants were Hamran, Eshban, Ithran, and Cheran.
1.42:
Ezer’s descendants were Bilhan, Zaavan, and Jaakan.
Dishan’s descendants were Uz and Aran.
1.43: Here’s a list of kings who reigned in the land of Edom before any king reigned over the Israelis, beginning with Beor’s son Bela (his city was named Dinhabah).
1.44: After Bela died, Zerah’s son Jobab from Bozrah succeeded him.
1.45: After Jobab died, Husham from the land of the Temanites succeeded him.
1.46: After Husham died, Bedad’s son Hadad, who defeated Midian in the country of Moab, succeeded him. His city was named Avith.
1.47: After Hadad died, Samlah from Masrekah succeeded him.
1.48: After Samlah died, Shaul from Rehoboth on the Euphrates River succeeded him.
1.49: After Shaul died, Achbor’s son Baal-hanan succeeded him.
1.50: After Baal-hanan died, Hadad succeeded him. His city was named Pai, and his wife’s name was Mehetabel. She was the daughter of Matred, who was the daughter of Me-zahab.
1.51:
Then Hadad died.
The chiefs of Edom included the chiefs of Timna, Aliah, Jetheth,
1.54: Magdiel, and Iram—these are the clans of Edom.

2.1: Here’s a list of Israel’s sons: Reuben, Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, Zebulun,
2.2: Dan, Joseph, Benjamin, Naphtali, Gad, and Asher.
2.3: Judah’s three sons Er, Onan, and Shelah were born to him through Bath-shua, a Canaanite. Er, Judah’s firstborn, became wicked in the Lord’s sight, so he put him to death.
2.4: Judah’s daughter-in-law Tamar also bore him Perez and Zerah, so Judah had five sons in all.
2.5: Perez’s sons were Hezron and Hamul.
2.6: Zerah had five sons in all: Zimri, Ethan, Heman, Calcol, and Dara.
2.7: Carmi’s son was Achar, who became Israel’s troublemaker by transgressing the Lord’s commandment regarding things that were to be destroyed.
2.9: Hezron’s sons born to him were Jerahmeel, Ram, and Chelubai.
2.10: Ram fathered Amminadab, and Amminadab fathered Nahshon, who was leader of the descendants of Judah.
2.11: Nahshon fathered Salma, Salma fathered Boaz,
2.12: Boaz fathered Obed, and Obed fathered Jesse.
2.13: Jesse fathered Eliab his firstborn, Abinadab his second born, Shimea his third born,
2.14: Nethanel his fourth born, Raddai his fifth born,
2.15: Ozem his sixth born, David his seventh born;
2.16:
along with their sisters Zeruiah and Abigail.
Zeruiah’s three sons were Abishai, Joab, and Asahel.
2.17: Abigail bore Amasa, whose father was Jether the Ishmaelite.
2.18: Hezron’s son Caleb had children by his wife Azubah and by Jerioth. These were her sons: Jesher, Shobab, and Ardon.
2.19: When Azubah died, Caleb married Ephrath, who bore him Hur.
2.20: Hur fathered Uri, and Uri fathered Bezalel.
2.21: Later, Hezron married the daughter of Machir, who had fathered Gilead. He married her when he was 60 years old, and she bore him Segub.
2.22: Segub fathered Jair, who had 23 towns in the land of Gilead.
2.23: But Geshur and Aram took 60 towns from Gilead, including Havvoth-jair and Kenath, along with their villages. All these were descendants of Machir, who fathered Gilead.
2.24: After Hezron died in Caleb-ephrathah, Abijah wife of Hezron bore him Ashhur, who fathered Tekoa.
2.25: The descendants of Jerahmeel, the firstborn of Hezron, were Ram his firstborn, Bunah, Oren, Ozem, and Ahijah.
2.26: Jerahmeel also had another wife, whose name was Atarah; she was the mother of Onam.
2.27: The descendants of Ram, firstborn of Jerahmeel were Maaz, Jamin, and Eker.
2.28:
Onam’s descendants were Shammai and Jada.
Shammai’s descendants were Nadab and Abishur.
2.29: Abishur’s wife was named Abihail. She bore him Ahban and Molid.
2.30: Nadab’s descendants were Seled and Appaim. Seled died childless.
2.31: Appaim’s son was Ishi. Ishi’s son was Sheshan. Sheshan’s son was Ahlai.
2.32: Shammai’s brother Jada’s descendants were Jether and Jonathan, but Jether died childless.
2.33: Jonathan’s descendants were Peleth and Zaza. These were the descendants of Jerahmeel.
2.34: Now Sheshan had no sons, only daughters. However, Sheshan had an Egyptian slave named Jarha.
2.35: So Sheshan gave his daughter in marriage to his slave Jarha, and she bore him Attai.
2.36: Attai fathered Nathan, and Nathan fathered Zabad.
2.37: Zabad fathered Ephlal, Ephlal fathered Obed,
2.38: Obed fathered Jehu, Jehu fathered Azariah,
2.39: Azariah fathered Helez, Helez fathered Eleasah,
2.40: Eleasah fathered Sismai, Sismai fathered Shallum.
2.41: Shallum fathered Jekamiah, and Jekamiah fathered Elishama.
2.42:
Jerahmeel’s brother Caleb’s descendants were his firstborn Mesha, who fathered Ziph.
The descendants of Mareshah, who fathered Hebron, were as follows:
2.43: Hebron’s descendants were Korah, Tappuah, Rekem, and Shema.
2.44:
Shema fathered Raham, who fathered Jorkeam.
Rekem fathered Shammai.
2.45: Shammai’s descendants included Maon, who fathered Beth-zur.
2.46:
Caleb’s mistress Ephah also bore Haran, Moza, and Gazez.
Haran fathered Gazez.
2.47: Jahdai’s descendants were Regem, Jotham, Geshan, Pelet, Ephah, and Shaaph.
2.48: Caleb’s mistress Maacah bore Sheber, Tirhanah,
2.49: and Shaaph, who fathered Madmannah. Sheva fathered Machbenah and Gibe. Caleb’s daughter was Achsah.
2.50:
These were Caleb’s descendants.
The son of Hur, the firstborn of Ephrathah, was Shobal, who fathered Kiriath-jearim,
2.51: Salma, who fathered Bethlehem, and Hareph, who fathered Beth-gader.
2.52: Shobal, who fathered Kiriath-jearim, had other sons, including Haroeh, half of the Menuhoth.
2.53: The families of Kiriath-jearim included the Ithrites, the Puthites, the Shumathites, and the Mishraites. The Zorathites and the Eshtaolites came from them.
2.54: Salma’s descendants were Bethlehem, the Netophathites, Atroth-beth-joab, and half of the Manahathites, the Zorites.
2.55: The families of the scribes who lived at Jabez included the Tirathites, the Shimeathites, and the Sucathites. These are the Kenites who came from Hammath, who fathered the house of Rechab.

3.1: These are David’s descendants who were born to him in Hebron: Amnon his firstborn by Ahinoam the Jezreelite, Daniel his second born by Abigail the Carmelite,
3.2: Absalom his third born by Maacah daughter of King Talmai of Geshur, Adonijah his fourth born by Haggith,
3.3: Shephatiah his fifth born by Abital, and Ithream his sixth born by his wife Eglah.
3.4:
These six were born to him in Hebron, where he reigned for seven years and six months.
He reigned 33 years in Jerusalem.
3.5: These four children were born to David by Bath-shua daughter of Ammiel while he was living in Jerusalem: Shimea, Shobab, Nathan, and Solomon,
3.6: followed by nine more: Ibhar, Elishama, Eliphelet,
3.9: All these were David’s sons, besides children born to his mistresses. Tamar was their sister.
3.10: Solomon’s descendants included Rehoboam, his son Abijah, his son Asa, his son Jehoshaphat,
3.11: his son Joram, his son Ahaziah, his son Joash,
3.12: his son Amaziah, his son Azariah, his son Jotham,
3.13: his son Ahaz, his son Hezekiah, his son Manasseh,
3.14: his son Amon, and his son Josiah.
3.15: Josiah’s descendants included Johanan his firstborn, his second born Jehoiakim, his third born Zedekiah, and his fourth born Shallum.
3.16: Jehoiakim’s descendants included his son Jeconiah, and his son Zedekiah.
3.17: The descendants of Jeconiah, who was taken captive to Babylon, included his son Shealtiel,
3.18: Malchiram, Pedaiah, Shenazzar, Jekamiah, Hoshama, and Nedabiah.
3.19:
Pedaiah’s descendants included Zerubbabel and Shimei.
Zerubbabel’s descendants included Meshullam and Hananiah, along with Shelomith their sister
3.20: and five others: Hashubah, Ohel, Berechiah, Hasadiah, and Jushab-hesed.
3.21: Hananiah’s descendants included Pelatiah and Jeshaiah, his son Rephaiah, his son Arnan, his son Obadiah, and his son Shecaniah.
3.22: Shecaniah’s son was Shemaiah, and the six sons of Shemaiah were Hattush, Igal, Bariah, Neariah, and Shaphat.
3.23: The three sons of Neariah were Elioenai, Hizkiah, and Azrikam.
3.24: The seven sons of Elioenai were Hodaviah, Eliashib, Pelaiah, Akkub, Johanan, Delaiah, and Anani.

4.1: Judah’s descendants were Perez, Hezron, Carmi, Hur, and Shobal.
4.2: Shobal’s son Reaiah fathered Jahath, and Jahath fathered Ahumai and Lahad. These were the families of the Zorathites.
4.3: These were the descendants of the ancestor of Etam: Jezreel, Ishma, and Idbash; and their sister’s name was Hazzelelponi.
4.4:
Penuel fathered Gedor and Ezer fathered Hushah.
These were the descendants of Hur, Ephrathah’s firstborn, who fathered Bethlehem:
4.5: Tekoa’s father Ashhur had two wives, Helah and Naarah.
4.6: Naarah bore him these sons: Ahuzzam, Hepher, Temeni, and Haahashtari.
4.7: The sons of Helah were Zereth, Izhar, and Ethnan.
4.8: Koz fathered Anub, Zobebah, and the families of Harum’s son Aharhel.
4.9: Jabez enjoyed more honor than his relatives—his mother named him Jabez, she said, “because I bore him in pain.”
4.10: Later on, Jabez called on the God of Israel, asking him, “…whether you would bless me again and again, enlarge my territory, keep your power with me, keep me from evil, and keep me from harm!” And God granted what he had requested.
4.11: Chelub, Shuhah’s brother, fathered Mehir, who fathered Eshton.
4.12: Eshton fathered Beth-rapha, Paseah, and Tehinnah, who fathered Ir-nahash. These are the men of Recah.
4.13:
Kenaz’s descendants were Othniel and Seraiah.
Othniel’s descendants were Hathath
4.14:
and Meonothai, who fathered Ophrah.
Seraiah fathered Joab, who fathered the Ge-harashim, because they became artisans.
4.15:
The descendants of Jephunneh’s son Caleb were Iru, Elah, and Naam.
Elah’s son was Kenaz.
4.16: Jehallelel’s descendants were Ziph, Ziphah, Tiria, and Asarel.
4.17:
Ezrah’s descendants were Jether, Mered, Epher, and Jalon.
Mered’s wife conceived Miriam, Shammai, and Ishbah, who fathered Eshtemoa.
4.18: Then his Judean wife bore Jered, who fathered Gedor and then Heber, who fathered Soco and Jekuthiel, who fathered Zanoah. These are the descendants of Bithiah, daughter of Pharaoh, whom Mered married.
4.19: The descendants of Hodiah’s wife, Naham’s sister, fathered Keilah the Garmite and Eshtemoa the Maacathite.
4.20:
Shimon’s descendants were Amnon, Rinnah, Ben-hanan, and Tilon.
Ishi’s descendants were Zoheth and Ben-zoheth.
4.21: The descendants of Judah’s son Shelah were Er, who fathered Lecah, Laadah (who fathered Mareshah and the families who belonged to the guild of linen workers at Beth-ashbea),
4.22: Jokim, the men who lived in Cozeba, Joash, and Saraph (who married Moabite families), and Jashubi-lehem. (The records are ancient.)
4.23: These people were potters who lived in Netaim and Gederah in service to their king, who lived there.
4.24: Simeon’s descendants were Nemuel, Jamin, Jarib, Zerah, Shaul,
4.25: his son Shallum, his son Mibsam, and his son Mishma.
4.26: Mishma’s descendants were his son Hammuel, his son Zaccur, and his son Shimei.
4.27: Shimei had 16 sons and six daughters, but his relatives did not have many children, nor did their entire family multiply like the Judeans did.
4.28: They lived in Beer-sheba, Moladah, Hazar-shual,
4.31: Beth-marcaboth, Hazar-susim, Beth-biri, and Shaaraim. These were their cities until David began to reign.
4.32: Their cities were Etam, Ain, Rimmon, Tochen, and Ashan, for a total of five cities,
4.33:
along with all their settlements that surrounded these cities as far as Baal—this is their settlement history.
They kept this genealogical record for themselves:
4.35: Joel, Joshibiah’s son Jehu (who was the grandson of Seraiah and great-grandson of Asiel),
4.36: Elioenai, Jaakobah, Jeshohaiah, Asaiah, Adiel, Jesimiel, Benaiah,
4.37: Shiphi’s son Ziza (who was the grandson of Shiphi, who was fathered by Allon, who was fathered by Jedaiah, who was fathered by Shimri, who was fathered by Shemaiah)—
4.38: these people, enumerated by name, were leaders in their respective families, and their clans grew to be very abundant.
4.39: They journeyed as far as the entrance of Gedor on the east side of the valley in order to find pasture for their flocks.
4.40: They discovered abundant and excellent grazing lands there, where the land was very broad, secure, and tranquil, because the former inhabitants there were descendants of Ham.
4.41: Later on, during the reign of King Hezekiah of Judah, these people, enumerated by name, came and attacked both their homes and the Meunim who had settled there and who remain exterminated to this day. They settled down there, taking their place, because there was pasture there for their flocks.
4.42: Some of them—that is, 500 Simeonite men—went to Mount Seir. Under the leadership of Ishi’s sons Pelatiah, Neariah, Rephaiah, and Uzziel,
4.43: they destroyed the survivors of the Amalekites who had escaped, and they have lived there to this day.

5.1: Here is a record of the descendants of Reuben, Israel’s firstborn. (He was the firstborn, but because he defiled his father’s marriage bed, his birthright was transferred to the descendants of Israel’s son Joseph. As a result, Reuben is not enrolled in the genealogy according to the birthright.
5.2: Even though Judah became prominent among his relatives—that is, the Commander-in-chief will be his descendant—nevertheless the right of the firstborn went to Joseph.)
5.3: The descendants of Reuben, Israel’s firstborn, included Hanoch, Pallu, Hezron, and Carmi.
5.4: Joel’s descendants were his son Shemaiah, his son Gog, his son Shimei,
5.5: his son Micah, his son Reaiah, his son Baal,
5.6: and his son Beerah, whom King Tiglath-pileser of Assyria carried away into exile, and who was a governor of the descendants of Reuben.
5.7: His relatives, listed by families when the genealogy was enrolled according to their generations, included the chief, Jeiel, Zechariah,
5.8: and Azaz’s son Bela, grandson of Shema, and great-grandson of Joel, who lived in Aroer, near Nebo and Baal-meon.
5.9: He also lived eastward as far as the entrance to the wilderness this side of the Euphrates River, because their cattle had increased in the territory of Gilead.
5.10: During the reign of Saul they declared war on the Hagrites, who fell in battle by their hand. They lived in their tents throughout all of east Gilead.
5.11: Gad’s descendants lived beside them in the land of Bashan as far as Salecah:
5.12: They included Joel their chief, Shapham their second in command, Janai, and Shaphat, who lived in Bashan.
5.13: Their seven relatives, according to the households of their clans, included Michael, Meshullam, Sheba, Jorai, Jacan, Zia, and Eber.
5.14: These were the descendants of Huri’s son Abihail, who was fathered by Jaroah, who was fathered by Gilead, who was fathered by Michael, who was fathered by Jeshishai, who was fathered by Jahdo, and who was fathered by Buz:
5.15: Abdiel’s son Ahi, who was the grandson of Guni, was chief in their clan.
5.16: They lived in Gilead, in Bashan and its villages, and in all the surrounding suburbs of Sharon as far as their borders.
5.17: All of them were enrolled by genealogies during the reign of King Jotham of Judah and during the reign of King Jeroboam of Israel.
5.18: The descendants of Reuben, the descendants of Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh produced 44,700 valiant soldiers expert in shield, sword, and bow. Trained in warfare, they were equipped to serve at a moment’s notice.
5.19: They fought in battle against the Hagrites, Jetur, Naphish, and Nodab.
5.20: When they received assistance against them, the Hagrites and all of their allies were handed over to their control, because they cried out to God during the battle. He honored their entreaty, because they had placed their trust in him.
5.21: They captured 50,000 camels, 250,000 sheep, 2,000 donkeys, and 100,000 war captives from their possessions.
5.22: Many fell slain, because the battle’s outcome was directed by God. They lived in their territory until the exile.
5.23: The half-tribe of Manasseh lived in the land, spread out from Bashan to Baal-hermon, including Senir and Mount Hermon.
5.24: These were the leaders of their clans: Epher, Ishi, Eliel, Azriel, Jeremiah, Hodaviah, and Jahdiel—they were mighty warriors, well known men, and leaders of their clans.
5.25: But they were unfaithful to the God of their ancestors by prostituting themselves to the gods of the peoples of the land, whom God had exterminated right in front of them.
5.26: So the God of Israel incited King Pul of Assyria (also known as King Tiglath-pileser of Assyria), who took them prisoner and brought the descendants of Reuben, the descendants of Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh to Halah, Habor, Hara, and to the Gozan River, where they remain to this day.

6.1: Levi’s descendants included Gershom, Kohath, and Merari.
6.2: Kohath’s sons included Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel.
6.3: Amram’s descendants included Aaron, Moses, and Miriam. Aaron’s sons included Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.
6.4: Eleazar fathered Phinehas, Phinehas fathered Abishua,
6.5: Abishua fathered Bukki, Bukki fathered Uzzi,
6.6: Uzzi fathered Zerahiah, Zerahiah fathered Meraioth,
6.7: Meraioth fathered Amariah, Amariah fathered Ahitub,
6.8: Ahitub fathered Zadok, Zadok fathered Ahimaaz,
6.9: Ahimaaz fathered Azariah, Azariah fathered Johanan,
6.10: and Johanan fathered Azariah, who served as priest in the Temple that Solomon built in Jerusalem.
6.11: Azariah fathered Amariah, Amariah fathered Ahitub,
6.12: Ahitub fathered Zadok, Zadok fathered Shallum,
6.13: Shallum fathered Hilkiah, Hilkiah fathered Azariah,
6.14: Azariah fathered Seraiah, and Seraiah fathered Jehozadak.
6.15: The Lord sent Jehozadak, Judah, and Jerusalem into exile, using Nebuchadnezzar to do it.
6.16: Levi’s descendants included Gershom, Kohath, and Merari.
6.17: These are the names of Gershom’s descendants: Libni and Shimei.
6.18: Kohath’s sons included Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel.
6.19:
Merari’s sons included Mahli and Mushi.
These are the clans of the descendants of Levi according to their ancestry:
6.20: Gershom’s clan included his son Libni, his son Jahath, his son Zimmah,
6.21: his son Joah, his son Iddo, his son Zerah, and his son Jeatherai.
6.22: Kohath’s descendants included Amminadab, his son Korah, his son Assir,
6.23: his son Elkanah, his son Ebiasaph, his son Assir,
6.24: his son Tahath, his son Uriel, his son Uzziah, and his son Shaul.
6.25: Elkanah’s descendants included Amasai and Ahimoth,
6.26: his son Elkanah, his son Zophai, his son Nahath,
6.27: his son Eliab, his son Jeroham, and his son Elkanah.
6.28: Samuel’s descendants included Joel his firstborn and his second son Abijah.
6.29: Merari’s descendants included Mahli, his son Libni, his son Shimei, his son Uzzah,
6.30: his son Shimea, his son Haggiah, and his son Asaiah.
6.31: These are the men to whom David handed responsibility for music in the Temple of the Lord, after the ark came to rest there.
6.32: They ministered in song in front of the Tent of Meeting, until Solomon had built the Temple of the Lord in Jerusalem. They served in accordance with orders of service designated for them.
6.33: These are the men who served, including their descendants: From the descendants of Kohath, there was Heman the singer, who had been fathered by Joel, who had been fathered by Samuel,
6.34: who had been fathered by Elkanah, who had been fathered by Jeroham, who had been fathered by Eliel, who had been fathered by Toah,
6.35: who had been fathered by Zuph, who had been fathered by Elkanah, who had been fathered by Mahath, who had been fathered by Amasai,
6.36: who had been fathered by Elkanah, who had been fathered by Joel, who had been fathered by Azariah, who had been fathered by Zephaniah,
6.37: who had been fathered by Tahath, who had been fathered by Assir, who had been fathered by Ebiasaph, who had been fathered by Korah,
6.38: who had been fathered by Izhar, who had been fathered by Kohath, who had been fathered by Levi, who had been fathered by Israel.
6.39: There was also his brother Asaph, who stood to Heman’s right. Asaph had been fathered by Berechiah, who had been fathered by Shimea,
6.40: who had been fathered by Michael, who had been fathered by Baaseiah, who had been fathered by Malchijah,
6.41: who had been fathered by Ethni, who had been fathered by Zerah, who had been fathered by Adaiah,
6.42: who had been fathered by Ethan, who had been fathered by Zimmah, who had been fathered by Shimei,
6.43: who had been fathered by Jahath, who had been fathered by Gershom, and who had been fathered by Levi.
6.44: To Heman’s left were their relatives who were Merari’s sons: Ethan, who had been fathered by Kishi, who had been fathered by Abdi, who had been fathered by Malluch,
6.45: who had been fathered by Hashabiah, who had been fathered by Amaziah, who had been fathered by Hilkiah,
6.46: who had been fathered by Amzi, who had been fathered by Bani, who had been fathered by Shemer,
6.47: who had been fathered by Mahli, who had been fathered by Mushi, who had been fathered by Merari, who had been fathered by Levi,
6.48: along with their relatives, descendants of Levi who had been appointed for all the service of the tent of the Temple of God.

10.1: The Philistines were fighting against Israel, and each soldier of Israel fled before the Philistines. They fell slain on the mountain of Gilboa.
10.2: The Philistines followed after Saul and after his sons, and the Philistines struck down Jonathan, Abinadab, and Malchi-shua, Saul’s sons.
10.3: The heaviest fighting was against Saul, and when the archers who were shooting located Saul, he was gravely wounded by them.
10.4:
Saul ordered his armor bearer, “Draw your sword and run me through with it, or these uncircumcised people will come and abuse me.”
But his armor bearer did not want to do it because he was very frightened, so Saul took the sword and fell on it.
10.5: When his armor bearer saw that Saul was dead, he also fell on his sword and died.
10.6: Therefore Saul, his three sons, and all his entire household died together.
10.7: When that part of the army of Israel that was in the valley saw that the rest of the army of Israel had fled and that Saul and his sons were dead, they abandoned their cities and fled, and the Philistines came and occupied them.
10.8: The Philistines came to strip the dead the next day, and they found Saul dead on Gilboa mountain, along with his sons.
10.9: They stripped him, took his head and armor, and sent messengers throughout the territory of the Philistines to report the news to their idols and to the people.
10.10: Then they put Saul’s armor in the temple of their gods and fastened his skull to the wall of the temple of Dagon.
10.11: When all the residents of Jabesh-gilead heard everything that the Philistines had done to Saul,
10.12: every valiant soldier got up, removed the bodies of Saul and his sons, took them to Jabesh, and buried their bones under the tamarisk tree in Jabesh. Then they fasted for seven days.
10.13: So Saul died for his transgressions; that is, he acted unfaithfully to the Lord by transgressing the message from the Lord (which he did not keep), by consulting a medium for advice,
10.14: and by not seeking counsel from the Lord, who therefore put him to death and turned the kingdom over to Jesse’s son David.

11.1: Later on, all of Israel gathered together at Hebron in order to tell David, “Look, we’re your own flesh and blood!
11.2: Even back when Saul was ruling as king, you kept on leading the army of Israel out to battle and bringing them in again. The Lord your God told you, ‘You yourself will shepherd my people Israel and will be Commander-in-Chief over my people Israel.’”
11.3: So all the elders of Israel approached the king at Hebron, where David entered into a covenant in the presence of the Lord. Then they anointed David to be king over Israel, just as the Lord had sent word through Samuel.
11.4: Later, David and all of Israel marched to Jerusalem (then known as Jebus, where the Jebusites lived when they inhabited the land).
11.5: The inhabitants of Jebus told David, “You’re not coming in here!” Nevertheless, David captured the fortress of Zion, now known as the City of David.
11.6: David had announced, “Whoever first attacks the Jebusites will be appointed chief and commander.” When Zeruiah’s son Joab went up first, he became chief.
11.7: David occupied the fortress, so it was named the City of David after him.
11.8: He built up the walls surrounding the city in a complete circle from the terrace ramparts, and Joab repaired the rest of the city.
11.9: David became more and more prestigious because the Lord of the Heavenly Armies was with him.
11.10: These are the leaders of the elite warriors who were strong supporters of David in his kingdom, along with all of Israel, in keeping with the message from the Lord concerning Israel.
11.11: This record of the warriors who were for David included Hachmoni’s son Jashobeam, leader of the platoons, who killed 300 with his spear in a single encounter.
11.12: Next to him among the Three Warriors was Dodo the Ahohite’s son Eleazar.
11.13: He was with David at Pas-dammim when the Philistines were there to engage them in battle. There was a field planted with barley, and the army had run away from the Philistines,
11.14: but they took a defensive stand in the middle of the field and killed the Philistines while the Lord saved them by means of a great victory.
11.15: Later, the Three Warriors went down to David’s hideout at the cave of Adullam when the Philistine army was camping in the valley of giants.
11.16: David was living in that stronghold at the time, while a Philistine garrison was then at Bethlehem.
11.17: David expressed a longing, “Oh, how I wish someone would get me a drink of water from the Bethlehem well that’s by the city gate!”
11.18: So the Three Warriors broke through the Philistine ranks, drew some water from the Bethlehem well that was next to the city gate, and brought it back to David. But David refused to drink it, poured it out in the Lord’s presence, and
11.19: said in response, “May God forbid me to do this! I won’t drink the blood of these men, will I? After all, they risked their lives to bring it to me.” That’s why he wouldn’t drink it. The Three Warriors did these things.
11.20: Joab’s brother Abishai was the lieutenant in charge of the platoons. He used his spear to fight and kill 300 men, gaining a reputation distinct from the Three.
11.21: He was more well-known than the Three, but he never attained the stature of the Three.
11.22: Jehoiada’s son Benaiah, who was a valiant man, accomplished great things. He was from Kabzeel. He killed two men named Ariel from Moab and then he also went down into a pit and struck down a lion during a snow storm one day.
11.23: He also killed a soldier from Egypt of enormous height—five cubits tall. The Egyptian carried a spear comparable in size to a weaver’s beam, but Benaiah attacked him with a staff, snatched the spear out of the Egyptian’s hand and killed him with his own spear.
11.24: Benaiah did things like this and gained a reputation comparable to the Three Warriors.

12.2: Equipped as archers, they could use both their right and left hands to shoot arrows and hurl stones. As descendants of Benjamin, they were Saul’s relatives.

12.7: and Jeroham’s sons Joelah and Zebadiah from Gedor.
12.8: Mighty and experienced warriors from the descendants of Gad joined David at his wilderness stronghold. They were expert handlers of both shield and spear, with hardened looks and as agile as a gazelle on a mountain slope.
12.9: Their leader was Ezer, Obadiah was second, Eliab third,
12.14: These descendants of Gad were army leaders. The least of them was equal to a hundred other soldiers and the greatest to a thousand.
12.15: These men crossed the Jordan in the first month of the year during flood season and chased out everyone in the valleys, to the east and to the west.
12.16: Later, some descendants of Benjamin and Judah approached David at his stronghold,
12.17: and David went out to meet them. He told them, “If you’ve come in peace to be of help to me, then you’ll have my commitment. But if you’ve come to betray me to my enemies, even though I’m innocent of wrongdoing, then may the God of our ancestors watch and judge.”
12.18:
Then the Spirit came upon Amasai, leader of the Thirty, and he said,
“David, we belong to you;
    we’re with you, son of Jesse!
Peace, peace to you,
    and peace to the one who helps you!
        For your deliverer is your God.”
So David received them and assigned them to be officers over troops.
12.19: Some of the descendants of Manasseh joined David when he was going to fight against Saul, accompanied by the Philistines. Even so, David was of no help to them, because the Philistine rulers were counseled to send him away. They told themselves, “He’s going to go over to his master Saul at the cost of our heads.”
12.20: As he traveled toward Ziklag, these descendants of Manasseh joined him: Adnah, Jozabad, Jediael, Michael, Jozabad, Elihu, and Zillethai, leaders in charge thousands in Manasseh.
12.21: They helped David against raiders, since they were all warriors and commanders in the army.
12.22: Indeed people kept coming to David every day to help him, until his army became a great, vast army.
12.23: What follows is a listing of the divisions of battle-ready troops who joined David in Hebron to turn the kingdom of Saul over to him, in accordance with what the Lord had spoken.
